bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kêtahtawê ayîsiyiniwak êh-mihcêtokamikisicik , kihtimiw êkotah pêyak oskinîkiw , kâkikê êh-pimisihk . Once upon a time, where some people dwelt, a certain youth was so lazy that he was always lying down.

piyis tân-tahtw_askiy , piyis watapiyah misiwê ôhpikiniyiwa , iyikohk êh-kihtimit . At last, after I don't know how many years, the fibrous roots of the white pine had grown up all round his body, so lazy was he.
kêtahtawê ê-pa-pimisihk , kâ-pê-kitôtiht . Then at one time, as he lay there, someone came and called to him.
êh-itâpit , iskwâhtêmihk kâ-paspâpiyit oskinîkiskwêwah nêwo . When he looked, there, peeping in at the door, were four young women.
mistahi mâh-miyosiyiwa . Every one of them was very pretty.

kîtimosinaw , itik ,
kîh-pa-pimisin watapîw-iyin , itik . “Our sweetheart,” they said to him, “has lain there long enough, has Pine-Root Man,” they said to him.
êkosi sipwêhtêyiwa . With that they were off.
waniskâpahtâw ; paspaskipayihêw owatapiyimah ; nawaswêw oskinîkiskwêwah . Up he leaped and ran; he ripped through his roots of the pine; he ran after the young women.
nêwiwak nâpêwak , êh-pimitisahwâcik wîcimosiwâwah . four were the men pursuing the sweethearts.
wâhyaw êkwah ê-ihtâcik , kêtahtawê nakiyiwah . Then when they had gone a long ways, presently the women stopped.

seg.q: nîtimosê , watapîw-iyin , nisîm awa kiwîh-wîhtamâtn tânisiy êsiyîhkâsot :
seg.gloss: “Sweetheart mine, Pine-Root Man, I shall tell you how my younger sister here is called:

p.seg: kwa sipwêhtêwak . Then they were off again.
mistahi misi-piwaniyiw . There was a terrible blizzard.
taswêkinêw otakohpah ; êkotah sîpâh pa-pimohtêwak . He spread out his blanket-robe; beneath it they walked along.
omâ k-ôsêhcâyik êh-otihtahkik , âstê-kîsikâyiw . When they reached that rise in the land, the sky grew clear again.
âsa mînah pêhikwak . Again the others waited for them.
kotak êkwah nisîm , nîtimosê , watapîw-iyin , mistahi kâ-kisihk isiyîhkâsôw , itêw . “And this other younger sister of mine, Pine-Root, my sweetheart, is called Very-Cold-Weather,” she told him.
êkosi minah sipwêhtêwak . With that they were off again.
ositiwâwah mitonih wiy-âhkwaciwak . their feet very nearly froze.
êtataw takohtêwak ; kêkâc kawaciwak . They barely got there; they were frozen near to falling.
êkosi êkwah sipwêhtêwak . Then again they set out.
kêtahtawê êkwah nâpêwak , têpwâtêw iskwêwah . Presently, from the men's party, he called out to the women.
cêskwah ! itêw ; “Wait!” he called to her; “Let me now tell you how this younger brother of mine is called:

seg.q: awa nisîm ka-wîhtamâtin nîstah êsiyîhkâsot : oskâcihko-kimiwan nêm îskoh k-ôsêhcâk .

p.seg: êkwah sipwêhtêwak . Then they were off.

seg.gloss: “Goodness me, really a beautiful name has our sweetheart!”

p.seg: kway êh-sipwêhtêyit , misi-kimiwaniyiw . Then, when they set out, it rained hard.
êkwah sipwêhtêwak . Again they set out.
âsa mînah têpwâtêw . Again he called to them.

seg.q: kotak nisîm ômis isiyîhkâsôw : kîsôpwêw nêm îskôh k-ôsêhcâk .
seg.gloss: “My other younger brother is called like this: Hot-Weather-up-to-yon-Hill.”

p.seg: êkwah ôk îskwêwak mostâpêkasêwak iskwêwak ispimihk isih . then those women went naked as they went upward. LB on {mostâpêkasêwak}: This feature certainly does not belong here; it spoils the climactic point of the next stroke.
êh-otihtahkik osêhcâw , pôni-kimiwan . When they reached the hill, it stopped raining.

hê êy ! itwêwak ;
tâpwê âyimaniyiw kîtimosinaw osîmah êsiyîhkâsôyit ! “Oh dear!” they cried; “Really, it is terrible, the way our sweetheart's younger brother is called!”

seg.q: êkwah niyah , nêm îskôh k-ôsêhcâk k-âsê-môhkitohtêw nitisiyîhkâson .
seg.gloss: “Now, as for me, [no translation] I am called.”

p.seg: tâpwê mistahê asêhtêwak ôki . Truly, at a great rate those persons walked backwards.

seg.gloss: “ [no translation] Truly beautiful is our sweetheart's name!”

p.seg: êkwah nôtokêsiw âh-asawâpamêw otawâsimisah . Now, the old woman was on the lookout for her children.

seg.gloss: “What on earth makes you act this crazy way?”

p.seg: awas ! nîtimosinân owîhôwin ! itwêwak . “Get away! Our sweetheart's name!” they cried. LB: That is, if the old woman discusses their action, she is in danger of unknowingly speaking her son-in-law's name, which, of course, is tabu to her.
wîkiwâw êh-otihtahkik , êkoyikohk kwayask pimohtêwak . When they reached their dwelling, only then did they walk properly.
kotak êkwah waskâhikanis namoya ê-kîsôwâyik , êkotah asiwasôwak ôkih môsâpêwak . Into another little house that was not heated the lone men were placed.
nama kêkway kotawânâpisk . There was no stove.
mitoni wîh-âhkwaciwak . They were very nearly frozen.

pîhcâyihk êkotah waskâhikanisihk mâ-môminêwak otêhiminah , âtah êh-pâh-pâhkaciyit miscikosah . in there in the little hut they were eating strawberries from the bush, even though the little trees were snapping in the cold.

êkwah awa kisêyiniw ,
ntawâpam ; t-ôsâmâskaciwak , itik owîkimâkanah . Then the old man of that place, “Go take a look at them; they will be freezing too stiff,” he was bidden by his wife.
kîh-mâ-môminêyiwah mînisah . they were eating berries from the bush.
kîwêw . He went back.
mâh-môminêwak , itah misawâc kiw-ôh-pimâtisiwakwê ! itwêw . “They are eating berries from the bush, they will be living on that, no doubt!” said he.
kîhtwâm êh-tipiskâyik âsa mînah ayiwâkês êkwah ksinâyiw . The next night it grew even colder.
âsay mînah pimotahkwêw . Again he shot an arrow.
âsa mînah môminêwak ayah misâskwatôminah . Again they ate berries from the bush, saskatoon-berries.
ntawi-paspâpiw nôtokêsiw . The old woman went and peeped in.

seg.gloss: “Those persons are eating berries from the bush, old man.
And here I am going hungry!

p.seg: êkwah mâcîtisahwâwak . Then they were driven off and away. LB: From here on the story is badly shortened.
wâpamêwak kwaskwêpayihôsah , êh-mihkosiyit . They saw a jumping-deer, a red one.
nawaswâtêwak . They chased it.
pimwêw ; môhtâskikanêhosôw . One shot at it; he pierced himself through the chest.
kîhtwâm kîskwêhkwasiw nôtokêsiw . Again the old woman talked in her sleep.

seg.q: êh-pawâtamân nnahâhkisîm iskah êh-nipahât kwaskwêpayihôsêh âh-mihkosiyit , otah isk êh-pimipahtât , êh-môwak .
seg.gloss: “It was that I dreamt that my son-in-law killed the red jumping-deer that ran by here, and that I ate it.”

p.seg: êkosi êkwah mâcîw ; wâpamêw ; pimwêw êkwah otâhk isih ; nipahêw . So then he went to hunt; he saw it; he shot it from behind; he killed it.
kîwêcitâpêw . He dragged it back.
pîhtokêw wîkiwâhk . He entered their dwelling.

seg.gloss: “Here is the creature the old woman wanted to eat!”

p.seg:
êh-yôhtânâhk nôtokêsiw ,
hê êy êy ! tâpwê nikakwâhyakihik , nipwêkanah ! When the old woman opened the door, “Dear me! Truly he brings calamity on me! My dream-guardian!”
misi-wîhkohtok ; iyawis pakâsimihk , itwêw . “Have a big feast; boil it whole,” he said.
êkwah ê-misi-wîhkohtocik , kitamwêwak . they gave a big feast and consumed it.
êkosi êkwah sâkôcihêw osikosah . And thus he overcame his mother-in-law.
êkwah acosisah osîhtâw nêô . Then he made four arrows.
êkwah itohtêw owîcêwâkanah itah kâ-kîh-nipahamiht . Then he went to where his companions had been killed. CHECK -amiht
ispâhkêw . He shot into the air.

seg.gloss: “Away, away, away! I shall be hitting you by accident!”

p.seg: kâ-cîpipayiyit , âsa mîna kotak ispâhkêw . They twitched a bit, and again he shot into the air.
kêyâpic êkos itêw , kâ-pasikosipahtâyit . He repeated his words, and the other rose to his feet and ran.
kêyâpit nîso pimisiniyiwah . Two still lay there.
waniskâpahtâyiwah . the other jumped to his feet.
êyakw ês âwa kâ-waniskâpahtât macihkiwis . Now he who jumped to his feet, it seems was Miatchihkiwis.
êhag ; êk êh-pimâtisiyin , mâka k-ôh-pîkiskwêyan , ayiwâk ihkin ! itwêw êsah . “Yes. If you were not alive, it would be strange that you are talking!” he said. CHECK ka-/kâ expansion
tâpwê nimiywêyihtên êh-pimâtisiyân ! hay hay hay hay ! itwêw êsah . “Really, I am glad I am alive! Hurrah, hurrah!” he said.
êkwah awa macihkiwis kîh-kîwêhtahiskwêwêw êsah êyokw ânih . And so now Matchihkiwis took home a woman for himself.
namoy êkoyikoh kinwâw âtayôhkêwin êh-kîsihtâyân . Not so very long is the sacred story which I have finished.
